review.title: A Framework for Comparing Groups of Documents
review.abstract: We present a general framework for comparing multiple groups of documents. A bipartite graph model is proposed where document groups are represented as one node set and the comparison criteria are represented as the other node set. Using this model, we present basic algorithms to extract insights into similarities and differences among the document groups. Finally, we demonstrate the versatility of our framework through an analysis of NSF funding programs for basic research.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction and Motivation
sections.text: Given multiple sets (or groups) of documents, it is often necessary to compare the groups to identify similarities and differences along different dimensions. In this paper, we present a general framework for making such comparisons to extract important findings. Indeed, many tasks in the real world can be formulated as a problem of comparing two or more groups of documents. Here, we offer two motivational examples. Program evaluations. To conduct better direct research efforts, funding organizations such as the National Science Foundation (NSF), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), and the Ministry of Defense (DoD) are often able to review research programs by their artifacts (e.g., abstracts, published descriptions, and other research descriptions). Such evaluations may include overlaps between different programs that indicate duplication of efforts.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We have presented a two-part graph model for making comparisons between large groups of documents and demonstrated how basic algorithms that use the model can identify trends and anomalies between document groups. As an example analysis, we have shown how our model can be used to better characterize and evaluate NSF research programs. In future work, we plan to apply alternative comparison criteria in our model, such as those derived from so-called entity recognition and paraphrase recognition.
